title: Where Do Property Taxes in the U.S. Go?
text:
Every week, Mansion Global poses a tax question to real estate tax attorneys. Here is this week’s question.



Q. Do all property taxes in the U.S. go to supporting the local public school system?



A. Revenue from property taxes pays for a lot more than schools in many places. These funds support the local community and county, and can be used to pay for everything from safety and sanitation to parks and transportation.



Take New Jersey, which had the country’s highest effective tax rate in 2018, according to ATTOM Data Solutions, a California-based data company.

Property taxes in the Garden State pay for schools, but also government administration, public safety and law enforcement, emergency services, road maintenance and myriad other services, according to Marc Pfeiffer, senior policy fellow and assistant director at the Bloustein Local Government Research Center at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, New Jersey.



“Property tax in New Jersey is strictly local. It does not affect the state government,” he said. “Decisions on how to spend it are made by local decision makers.”



A New Jersey homeowner pays property tax to their school district, the county government and local municipality, Mr. Pfeiffer said. Some areas may have additional levies to fund green spaces, libraries and fire departments, he added.

Texas, which had the third-highest effective tax rate in the U.S., according to ATTOM, has a similar structure. For example, in Austin, homeowners also pay city, county and school taxes, said Jim Popp, a partner of the Austin-based law firm Popp Hutcheson.



There, “local property taxes help to pay for public schools, city streets, county roads, police departments, fire protection and many other vital programs,” according to the Travis County Central Appraisal District’s website. Hospitals, emergency services, utilities and water-control districts are among the agencies supported by the county.
